questions.text: Which of the following cartilages form a complete ring?
questions.solution:
Cricoid cartilage forms a complete ring around the airway and this is the only laryngeal cartilage to do so.

Clinical significance:

  • Sellick's maneuver - Cricoid pressure is applied to occlude the esophagus without occluding the airway. It prevents regurgitation of gastric contents during intubation and rapid induction of anesthesia.
  • The cricoid cartilage is the narrowest part of the pediatric airway.

  • Vital statistics include -
    • Birth rate
    • Death rate
    • Natural growth rate
    • Life expectancy at birth
    • Mortality rate
    • Fertility rate

questions.text: A school-going child presents with a history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, mouth breathing, and impaired hearing. On examination, a high arched palate is noted. What is the management of this condition?
questions.solution: The given clinical picture is suggestive of adenoid hypertrophy. The best line of management is adenoidectomy with grommet insertion.

questions.text: In patients with methanol poisoning, what is the rationale behind treating them with ethanol?

choices.text: Metabolism of methanol is slowed down
Reacts with methanol to form an inactive metabolite
Ethanol reverses the actions of methanol

questions.solution:
Ethanol has a higher affinity for alcohol dehydrogenase than methanol. Hence, the metabolism of methanol is slowed down on ethanol administration.

Formic acid, the metabolite of methanol is highly toxic. Therefore, slowing down the metabolism reduces the toxic effects.

questions.text: The low pressure receptors are ______

choices.text: Stimulated by atrial systole and diastole

questions.solution:
The low-pressure receptors are stimulated by atrial systole and diastole

The low-pressure receptors are those in the great veins, right and left atria and pulmonary vessels.
Atrial stretch receptors are of two types:

  • Type A: discharge primarily during atrial systole
  • Type B: discharge primarily during late diastole

Distension of the atrial walls→stimulation of atrial receptors → Vasodilation, fall in BP and increased heart rate.

questions.text: Spermatogenesis is maintained by which hormone?
questions.solution:
All three of them (testosterone, FSH, LH) are required for spermatogenesis.

Pulses of hypothalamic GnRH stimulate the anterior pituitary to secrete FSH and LH, which then act on the testes

FSH acts on the Sertoli cells to stimulate spermatogenesis and inhibin secretion. LH acts on the Leydig cells to stimulate testosterone secretion. Testosterone, acting locally on the Sertoli cells, is essential for maintaining spermatogenesis.

questions.text: The condition shown in the given image is due to elevated levels of a particular hormone secreted from a pituitary tumor. This hormone is also seen to be elevated in all of the following, except
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the given image is Cushing's disease caused by a pituitary adenoma secreting adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). Levels of ACTH decrease at midnight, while asleep.

Cushing's syndrome is caused by hypersecretion of cortisol from the adrenal cortex. When Cushing’s syndrome is secondary to excessive secretion of ACTH by the anterior pituitary, it is referred to as Cushing’s disease.

Any type of physical or mental stress can increase the levels of ACTH to within minutes. This, in turn, elevates cortisol levels up to 20 times normal. Pain stimuli due to physical stress or tissue damage are transmitted to the median eminence of the hypothalamus which secretes corticotropin-releasing factor (CRF). Within minutes, this leads to large quantities of cortisol in the blood.

Mental stress may cause an equally rapid increase in ACTH secretion as a result of increased activity in the limbic system which transmits signals to the hypothalamus.

The secretory rates of CRF, ACTH, and cortisol are high in the early morning but low in the late evening. This is a result of a 24-hour cyclical alteration in the signals from the hypothalamus. When a person changes daily sleeping habits, the cycle changes correspondingly.

questions.text: Which of the following bones is most accurate for sex determination?
questions.solution:
The whole pelvis is the most reliable bone for sex determination.

Krogman’s degree of accuracy in sex determination from adult skeletal remains:

  • Entire skeleton – 100%
  • Pelvis alone – 95%
  • Skull alone – 90%
  • Pelvis plus skull – 98%
  • Long bones alone – 80-90%
  • Long bones and skull - 90-95%
  • Long bones and pelvis - >95%

questions.text: The most common complication of pathological myopia is_____.
questions.solution:
Macular degeneration is the most common complication of myopia, followed by rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.

Complications of pathological myopia include the following:

  • Macular degeneration
  • Retinal detachment
  • Complicated cataract
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Choroidal hemorrhage
  • Strabismus fixus convergence
  • Primary open-angle glaucoma, which is not a complication, but reported to occur in association with pathological myopia.

questions.text: A patient with vomiting and abdominal pain reports to the hospital following consumption of food at a fast-food restaurant two days back. On examination, he has yellowish discolouration of sclera and further investigations confirmed a case of Hepatitis A. Identify the true statement about this condition.

choices.text: 1% sodium hypochlorite is an effective disinfectant for reservoirs.
Sexual route is the major route of transmission.`
10% of the cases can transform into Hepatocellular carcinoma

questions.solution:
The true statement about this condition is that it causes mild illness in children.

Hepatitis A:

Modes of transmission

  • Fecal-oral route: This is the major route of transmission
  • Parenteral route
  • Sexual transmission

Incubation period:

  • 10 to 50 days (usually 14-28 days).

Clinical spectrum:

  • The onset of jaundice is gastrointestinal symptoms such often preceded by as nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and mild fever.
  • Jaundice may appear within a few days of the prodromal period, but anicteric hepatitis is more common.
  • Hepatitis A resolves completely in 98 percent of cases but relapse of symptoms are noted in 3-20 percent cases

Diagnosis:

  • Laboratory diagnosis of hepatitis A can be obtained by
    • Demonstration of HAV particles or specific viral antigens in the feces, bile, and blood.
    • Anti-HAV appears in the lgM fraction during the acute phase, peaking about 2 weeks after the elevation of liver enzymes. ELISA is the method of choice for measuring HAV antibodies.

Prevention and containment:

  • Control of reservoir: Use of 0.5 percent sodium hypochlorite has been strongly recommended as an effective disinfectant
  • Control of transmission: personal and community hygiene
  • 1 mg/L of free residual chlorine can cause the destruction of the virus in 30 minutes at pH values of 8.5 or less
  • Patients with the chronic liver disease are at increased risk for fulminant hepatitis A and should be vaccinated
  • Use of hepatitis A vaccine should be considered for pre-exposure prophylaxis

Vaccines:

  • Two types of hepatitis A vaccines are currently used
    • Formaldehyde-inactivated vaccines
    • Live attenuated vaccines
  • The complete vaccination schedule consists of 2 dose administration into the deltoid muscle. The interval between the first (primary) dose and second (booster) dose is commonly 6-12 months.
  • Following 2 doses of vaccine, the protective efficacy is about 94 percent.

questions.text:
Inferior thyroid artery supllies which of the following structures?
  1. Thyroid
  2. Parathyroid
  3. Esophagus
  4. Thymus
questions.solution:
All the given 4 structures are supplied by the Inferior thyroid artery.

Inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk, which in turn, is a branch of the first part of the subclavian artery.

Branches:

  • Pharyngeal branches (these supply the lower part of the pharynx):
    • Tracheal branches 
    • Oesophageal branches 
    • Inferior and ascending glandular branches supply the posterior and inferior regions of the thyroid gland, and anastomose with the contralateral inferior and ipsilateral superior thyroid arteries.
    • The ascending branch also supplies the parathyroid glands.
  • Ascending cervical artery
  • Inferior laryngeal
  • Muscular branches

Note: Thymic branches originating from the internal thoracic, inferior thyroid artery, and sometimes superior thyroid arteries supply the thymus and the surrounding mediastinal connective tissue.

questions.text: Most afferent fibers from the lateral geniculate body terminate in the primary visual cortex in ______.
questions.solution:
Most afferent fibres from the lateral geniculate body (LGB) terminate in the primary visual cortex in layer 4.

  • Both the magnocellular and parvocellular pathways from the LGB terminate in layer 4 of visual cortex.
  • Only the interlaminar pathway terminates in layers 2 and 3.

questions.text: According to WHO, which of the following are components of the Human Development Index (HDI)?

choices.text: Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and standard of living
Infant mortality rate, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate

questions.solution:
The components of the Human Development Index (HDI) include life expectancy at birth, literacy, and standard of living.

Human Development Index (HDI) is a measure of a country's average achievements in three dimensions of human development:

  • A long and healthy life, as measured by life expectancy at birth
  • Knowledge (literacy), as measured by mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling, and
  • A decent standard of living, as measured by GNI (gross national income) per capita.

HDI values range from 0 to 1, with 1 as the maximum value.

Note- Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate are components of the Physical quality of life index (PQLI).

questions.text: The largest part of cerebellum is:
questions.solution:
The largest part of the cerebellum is the middle lobe, also known as the posterior lobe.

The cerebellum consists of two hemispheres (right and left) joined by a median vermis. It is divided into three lobes:-

  • Anterior lobe - lies superiorly above the primary fissure
  • Middle lobe - lies inferiorly below the primary fissure. It is the largest lobe. It is also called the posterior lobe.
  • Flocculonodular lobe - lies posterior to the uvulonodular fissure

The cerebellam also has two surfaces - superior and inferior separated by a horizontal fissure. It is connected to the other parts of the central nervous system via three peduncles-

  • Superior cerebellar peduncle -connecting to the midbrain
  • Middle cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the pons
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the medulla oblongata

questions.text: Increased BMR is seen in _____
questions.solution:
Increased basal metabolic rate (BMR) is seen in Cachexia.

Basal metabolic rate (BMR) is the energy expenditure by the body when at rest measured about 12 hours after the last meal, and is dependant on the individual's weight, age, and gender.

Cachexia is seen in a number of chronic diseases. In this condition there is considerably more loss of body protein although protein synthesis is not affected. In cachexia, continuous release of cytokines in response to infections and cancer increases the catabolism of tissue protein by the ATP-dependent ubiquitin-proteasome pathway, thereby increasing energy expenditure. This leads to a considerable increase in the Basal Metabolic Rate.

Related Pearl: Basal Metabolic Rate

Hyperthyroidism

questions.text: Substrate level phosphorylation occurs in which of the following steps of the TCA cycle?

choices.text: Alpha keto glutarate to succinyl CoA

questions.solution:
Succinyl-CoA is converted to succinate by the enzyme succinate thiokinase or also called as succinyl-CoA synthetase.

GTP formation takes place in this step, and hence this is the one and only example of substrate-level phosphorylation in the TCA cycle.

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

questions.text: Which is the most aggressive type of lung cancer?
questions.solution:
Small-cell carcinoma of the lung is the most aggressive type of lung cancer.

This tumor originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells (Kulchitsky cells), which are present in the lining bronchial epithelium.

Histopathological examination of small cell lung carcinoma shows:

  • Clusters of small cells with scant cytoplasm
  • Ill-defined cell borders
  • Finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern)
  • Absent or inconspicuous nucleoli

The cells are round, oval, or spindle-shaped, and nuclear molding is prominent.

The image below shows the histopathological findings of small cell lung carcinoma.

questions.text: Beta hCG is structurally similar to which biochemical moiety?
questions.solution:
The Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) has a biological activity similar to that of Luteinizing Hormone (LH).

hCG is a glycoprotein produced by syncytiotrophoblast. It is made up of α and β subunits. Though the α subunit of hCG is similar to the α subunits of LH, FSH, and TSH, the β subunit has structural similarity to LH only. Hence, LH is a better answer than FSH. 

hCG is primarily luteinizing and luteotrophic. It appears to act on the same receptor as that of LH. The function of hCG is to prevent regression of the corpus luteum. It can be detected in blood as early as 6 days after conception and forms the basis of various tests used to identify pregnancy.

questions.text: The  visual field defect usually found in craniopharyngioma is?
questions.solution:
The visual field defect usually found in craniopharyngioma is bitemporal hemianopia.

Craniopharyngiomas are benign masses usually presenting in the suprasellar region arising near the pituitary stalk and can produce functional impairment of the hypophysis due to mass effect. The clinical features of craniopharyngiomas include headaches,visual field defects,growth failure and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypofunction. CT scan may show calcifications in the supra-sellar region. Treatment includes trans-sphenoidal resection of the tumour followed by adjuvant chemotherapy.

Lesions of the optic chiasma can cause bitemporal hemianopia.i.e, loss of vision in the temporal halves of both visual fields. Nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma at this level and hence, these fibers are compromised.

Other causes of chiasmal lesions are

  • Pituitary adenoma (most common)
  • Aneurysm of the anterior communicating artery
  • Meningioma
  • Glioma

Other options:

Option B) Binasal hemianopia is a rare visual field defect also caused due to lesions at the optic chiasma.  

Option C) Superior quadrantopia is also known as pie in the sky defect and is caused when lesions affect the inferior fibres of the optic radiations in the temporal lobe.  

Option D)Inferior quadrantopia is also known as pie on the floor defect and is caused due to lesions affecting the superior fibres of the optic radiations in the parietal lobe.

questions.text: Roll over phenomenon is a feature of
questions.solution:
Roll over phenomenon is seen in retrocochlear hearing loss.

With an increase in speech intensity above a particular level, the PB word score falls rather than maintain a plateau as in the cochlear type of sensorineural hearing loss.

PB words: Phonetically balanced words (single syllable words, e.g. pin, sin, day, bus, etc.)

questions.text: What is the Nalgonda technique used for?

choices.text: Defluoridation of water using lime and alum
Steeping pulses in hot water for toxin removal
Air floatation of grains to remove ergot

questions.solution:
Nalgonda technique is used for defluoridation of water which involves the addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration.

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5mg/L. It is endemic in parts of India- Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Nalgonda, Prakasam), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu. 

Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: (1.5mg/L) Occurs if excess fluoride is ingested during the period of tooth calcification, i.e. in the first 7 years of life. Best seen on the upper incisors and almost exclusively affects only permanent teeth. It causes mottling on dental enamel, the appearance of chalky-white patches on the teeth, and loss of shine in the early stages. The white spots progressively turn yellow and can even become brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a corroded appearance. 
  • Skeletal fluorosis: (3-6mg/L) Occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone and these are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.
  • Crippling fluorosis: (>10mg/L) Can lead to permanent disability. 

Genu valgum and osteoporosis of the lower limb are seen in a newer form of fluorosis in Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh. It is seen in people consuming jawar (sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

The given images show dental fluorosis and skeletal fluorosis (interosseous-membrane-calcification), respectively:

 

Interventions for Fluorosis 

  • Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). Running surface water contains lower quantities of fluorides than groundwater sources.
  • The National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur developed a technique for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment called the Nalgonda technique. 
  • Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.
  • The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age

Other options:

Superchlorination of water is the addition of large amounts of chlorine to the water, for disinfection. The excess is later removed. It is done for heavily polluted water with fluctuating quality.

Steeping pulses in hot water for toxin removal is done for Lathyrism. The toxin beta oxalyl amino alanine in its crystalline form is water-soluble. The pulse is soaked in boiling water for 2 hours and the water is drained off completely. It is then washed with clean water and dried. 

Air floatation of grains is done to remove ergot, which is a field fungus. It can be removed by floating the grains in 20% saltwater, air floatation, or hand picking.

questions.text: Which virus causes the cytopathic effect of cytoplasmic vacuolation?
questions.solution:
The cytopathic effect of cytoplasmic vacuolation is caused by the simian virus 40.

Many viruses modify the morphology of the cells in which they grow in culture. The cultures can be examined under a microscope to see certain changes. These changes are known as cytopathic effects. There are several viruses that cause these effects and are thus known as cytopathogenic viruses. These can be detected by light microscopy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an orphan drug?
questions.solution:
Acetaminophen is not an orphan drug. It is an essential drug.

Orphan drugs are drugs for rare diseases, special incentives are given by the government for the pharmaceutical companies for the development and marketing of orphan drugs.

Few examples of orphan drugs:

  • Miltefosine
  • Sodium nitrite
  • Succimer
  • Rifabutin
  • Liposomal amphotericin B
  • Digoxin antibody
  • Fomepizole

questions.text: C wave of JVP represents:

choices.text: Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

questions.solution:
'C' wave in JVP represents tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.

Characteristics of JVP :

  • a wave corresponds to atrial systole which causes regurgitation of some blood into the great veins.
  • c wave occurs due to the increase in atrial pressure caused by bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  • x descent occurs due to the fall in atrial pressure during ventricular systole due to pulling of valve leaflets.
  • v wave is seen at the end of ventricular contraction and occurs due to the slow venous filling which causes an increase in atrial pressure.
  • y descent occurs due to the passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with primary hyperoxaluria is most likely to have a deficiency of which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
A patient diagnosed with primary hyperoxaluria is most likely to have a glycine deficiency.

The defect in primary hyperoxaluria type I is the deficiency of the alanine glyoxalate aminotransferase in liver peroxisomes causing failure to catabolize glyoxylate formed by the deamination of glycine. This leads to a gross overproduction of oxalate, leading to the formation of oxalate stones and subsequent kidney damage.

The FDA recently approved Lumasiran, RNA interference therapeutic targeting glycolate oxidase as the first treatment for primary hyperoxaluria type 1 (PH1), a rare genetic disorder.

questions.text: A 21-year-old student presents with ocular redness, foreign body sensation, and excessive tearing following the use of a contact lens. An interface contrast microscopy from his corneal scraping is shown below. What would be the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the demonstration of polygonal cysts in interface contrast microscopy are suggestive of amoebic keratitis caused by acanthamoeba.

Acanthamoeba culbertsoni is an opportunistic protozoan pathogen. It exists as trophozoite form and resistant cystic form. Both these forms are infective. The trophozoite is large and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia (acanthopodia).

Human beings acquire the infection by inhalation of cysts or trophozoites, directly through traumatized skin or eyes, or ingestion of cysts.

It chiefly presents as two chronic conditions:

  • Acanthamoeba keratitis
  • Granulomatous amoebic encephalitis

Acanthamoeba keratitis is an infection of the eyes that typically develops from the entry of the amebic cyst through abrasions on the cornea. Most of the cases are associated with the use of contact lenses. 

Patients usually present with photophobia, excessive tearing, redness, and foreign body sensation and it can be bilateral in contact lens users.

Diagnosis of amoebic keratitis is made by the demonstration of the cyst in corneal scrapings by wet mount, histology, and culture. The cysts are smaller (12-25 micrometer) and polygonal or star-shaped.

Topical administration of biguanides or chlorhexidine with or without diamidine agents can be used for the management of acanthamoeba keratitis. In severe cases penetrating keratoplasty can be done.

The below image shows the ring lesion seen in acanthamoeba keratitis.

 

 

The below image shows cysts of acanthamoeba in lactophenol cotton blue staining.

Other options:

Option B- Naegleria fowleri causes a brain infection, primary amebic meningoencephalitis that leads to brain tissue destruction. Their cysts are spherical and have a smooth double wall. 

Option C- Entamoeba histolytica causes intestinal and extraintestinal amebiasis. Their cysts are spherical in shape. A mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form.  An amebic ulcer is a typical lesion seen in intestinal amebiasis which is a flask-shaped ulcer in cross-section. Amebic liver abscess is extraintestinal amebiasis which has a center of abscess that contains thick colored brown pus termed anchovy sauce pus.

Option D- Balamuthia mandrillaris is a free-living ameba that causes granulomatous amebic encephalitis. Their cyst is usually spherical and surrounded by a three-layered cyst wall.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins, when infused in supraphysiological doses, cause macular oedema and macular cysts?
questions.solution:
Macular cysts and oedema may develop in patients due to the infusion of supraphysiological doses of vitamin B3 (niacin toxicity).

The toxic effects of niacin include:

  • Flushing associated with skin dryness, itching, paresthesia, and headache. These effects may be seen with even a low dose of 30mg/day. Premedication with aspirin alleviates these symptoms (as these symptoms are mediated by prostaglandins)
  • Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
  • Hepatic toxicity, which presents as jaundice with elevated AST and ALT levels.
  • Fulminant hepatitis requiring liver transplantation.
  • Glucose intolerance
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Macular edema and macular cysts.

questions.text: The transdermal patch of the cholinesterase inhibitor,  _________ is available for use in Alzheimer's disease.
questions.solution:
The transdermal patch of the cholinesterase inhibitor rivastigmine is available for use in Alzheimer's disease. It can be applied for over 24 hours. Transdermal delivery reduces the fluctuation and avoids direct gastric irritation effects associated with oral formulations. 

Tacrine use is obsolete because of its association with hepatotoxicity. (Option A)

Donepezil and galantamine transdermal formulations are under development and yet to be available in the market. (Options B and D)

questions.text: Which of the following layers is responsible for maintaining the hydration and transparency of the cornea?
questions.solution:
The hydration level and transparency of the cornea is maintained mainly by the endothelial cells of the cornea. If the cornea becomes overhydrated, it begins to scatter light and gradually begins to lose its transparency

Endothelium possesses Na+/K+ ATPase, which keeps the corneal stroma in a relatively dehydrated state. This helps in maintaining the transparency of the cornea. 

Endothelial cells decrease in number with age.

Other factors contributing to the transparency of the cornea are as follows:

  • Regular arrangement of corneal lamellae (Maurice theory)
  • Peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae (Goldmann theory)
  • Avascularity of the cornea
  • A balance between the intraocular pressure (IOP) and swelling pressure

The different layers of cornea:

  • Epithelium
  • Bowman’s membrane
  • Stroma (substantia propria)
  • Dua’s layer (pre-Descemet’s layer)                 
  • Descemet’s membrane
  • Endothelium

questions.text: Stimulation of which of the following regions promotes a 'sense of reward' in human beings?
questions.solution:
Major reward centers are located along the course of the medial forebrain bundle, especially in the lateral and ventromedial nuclei of the hypothalamus.

It is interesting to note that in the lateral nucleus of hypothalamus, weak stimulus produces a sense of pleasure whereas a strong stimulus produces rage. This phenomenon occurs in many areas where a weak stimulus produces a sense of reward while stronger ones produce a sense of punishment.

questions.text: The predominant type of collagen in the sclera is __________.
questions.solution:
Collagen type I is the predominant type of collagen found in the sclera. In fact, collagen forms 50 to 75% of the dry weight of the sclera.

Type II is absent in the sclera. It is rather found in the vitreous body of the eye.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best level of prevention of breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Early diagnosis and treatment is the best level of prevention of breast cancer. It is a secondary level of prevention.

The earlier a disease is diagnosed and treated, the better is the prognosis. The occurrence of secondary cases or any long term disability can be prevented. This is of particular importance in chronic diseases.

Early diagnosis and treatment is not as effective and economical as primary prevention. However, it may be critically important in reducing the high morbidity and mortality in diseases such as essential hypertension, cancer cervix and breast cancer.

questions.text: Muscle attached to the area marked in the diagram below:
questions.solution:
The image above shows the radius, identified by the radial head at the elbow joint. The arrow points to a raised area, which is the Radial Tuberosity.

Biceps Brachii is attached to radial tuberosity.

Biceps Brachii

Origin:

  • Short head arises from the apex of the coracoid process
  • Long head arises from the supraglenoid tubercle of the scapula

Insertion:

  • The two tendons end in a flattened tendon and attached to the radial tuberosity. 

Nerve supply:

  • Musculocutaneous Nerve (C5, C6)

questions.text: Fungal spores formed by the condensation of hyphal element:
questions.solution:
Arthospores are asexual spores that are formed along the mycelium/hyphae by segmentation and condensation of hyphae.

Arthrospores are commonly formed by dermatophytes, especially those belonging to the genus Trichophyton. Dimorphic fungi like Coccidiodes sp also form them.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on spore formation

It is classified into 4 types:

Glomeromycota:

  • Lower fungi with non-septate hyphae.
  • Asexual spores are called sporangiospores – within swollen sac-like structure called sporangia
  • Sexual spores are called zygospores and oospores

 

Ascomycota: 

  • Asexual spores are called conidia.
  • Sexual spores are called ascospores - formed within a sac or ascus.

 

Basidiomycota:

  • Asexual spores are called conidia.
  • Sexual spores are called basidiospores (on a basidium or base).

 

Deuteromycetes: (fungi imperfecti or hypomycetes) – sexual stages yet to be discovered.

questions.text: What type of speech pathology will be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Rhinolalia aperta/hypernasality will be seen in this condition of cleft palate.

Rhinolalia aperta(hypernasality) is a condition in which words that have little resonance, are resonated in the nose. This occurs when the nasopharynx cannot be cut off from the oropharynx or when there is abnormal communication between the oral and nasal cavities

Rhinilalia clausa (OptionA) is the lack of nasal resonance for words that are normally resonated in the nasal cavity such as m, n, and ng. It occurs due to blockage of the nose or nasopharynx.

Rhinolalia clausa
(Hyponasality)		 Rhinolalia aperta
(Hypernasality)
Common cold Velopharyngeal insufficiency
Nasal allergy Congenitally short soft palate
Nasal polypi Submucous palate
Nasal growth Large nasopharynx
Adenoids Cleft of the soft palate
Nasopharyngeal mass Paralysis of the soft palate
Familial speech pattern Post adenoidectomy
Habitual Oronasal fistula
  Familial speech pattern
  Habitual

Other options:

Option C: Puberphonia is a condition seen in emotionally labile adolescent males. They continue to speak in the prepubertal high-pitched voice. Gutzmann's pressure test is positive when pressing the thyroid prominence in a backward and downward direction relaxes the overstretched cords and produces a low-tone voice. The treatment is speech therapy.

Option D: Androphonia is a voice disorder where a person’s voice sounds unnaturally deep, often resembling a male voice. It typically occurs due to hormonal imbalances, vocal cord abnormalities, or conditions like puberphonia in females.

questions.text: A contraceptive ‘Z’ is used by 100 couples for a continuous period of 2 years. During this period, 20 women become pregnant despite using ‘Z’. What is the pearl index of ‘Z’?
questions.solution:
Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure

In this scenario, the total accidental pregnancies are 20.

The total months of exposure are 24 months for each woman. Hence, total months of exposure for 100 women is 24 x 100 = 2400. (We arrive at this as there are 100 couples who are exposed to the method.)

Pearl index = 20 x 1200/2400 = 10 per HWY

questions.text: Which of the following acts to increase the release of calcium ions from the endoplasmic reticulum of a smooth muscle?
questions.solution:
In response to a stimulus, the efflux of calcium from intracellular stores occurs through an Inositol triphosphate receptor (IP3R)- Ca+2 channel.

The source of Ca+2 in smooth muscle contraction can be different depending on the activating stimulus.

  • The influx from the extracellular site through voltage or ligand-gated Ca+2 channels in the plasma membrane
  • Efflux from intracellular stores (eg, sarcoplasmic reticulum) through the RyR and the inositol triosephosphate receptor (IP3R).

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with complaints of passing profuse loose stools which looked like rice water for the past 3 days. There's a history of similar symptoms in the family. Stool samples were sent to the lab for analysis and the test given in the image is performed. Identify this test.
questions.solution:
The given case scenario of passing profuse rice-water stools suggests a diagnosis of cholera. The test shown in the above image is the string test and it is performed to identify Vibrio cholerae.

To perform the string test, a loopful of the bacterial culture is mixed with a drop of 0.5% sodium deoxycholate in saline on a slide. The bacterial cells of Vibrio cholerae are lysed by sodium deoxycholate, causing the suspension to lose its turbidity and become mucoid. A string is formed when the loop is drawn away from the suspension.

Note: The duodenal string test refers to the Entero test performed for the diagnosis of giardiasis.

questions.text: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the immunization programme?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a ten-year-old schoolchild will be administered the TT/Td vaccine according to the National Immunization Schedule.

The Tetanus and adult diphtheria (Td) vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen (d) as recommended for older children and adults. The MoHFW recommends the replacement of TT vaccine with Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5ml is administered in the intramuscular route in the upper arm.

Scheduled to be administered at 10 and 16 years of age.

For pregnant women :

  • Td-1: early in pregnancy
  • Td-2: 4 weeks after Td-1
  • Td (Booster): if pregnancy occurs within 3 years of last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were received.

Other options:

Option A - According to the National Immunization Schedule, BCG should be given at birth or as early as possible up to 1 year of age. It provides protection against CNS and disseminated TB. A dose of 0.1 ml is administered intradermally in the left upper arm.

Option B - Measles/MR is given at 9 completed months (1st dose) and a second dose is given at 16-24 months. Measles can be given till 5 years of age. A dose of 0.5ml is administered subcutaneously in the right upper arm.

Option D - DPT vaccine is administered as a part of the pentavalent vaccine at the 6th, 10th and 14th weeks of life. DPT booster doses are administered at 16-24 months (first booster) and 5-6 years (second booster). It can be administered until 7 years of age (with booster doses). A dose of 0.5ml is administered in the anterolateral aspect of the mid-thigh. The 2nd booster dose can be administered in the upper arm.

questions.text: Which organism has the following cell wall structure?
questions.solution:
The presence of teichoic acid and lipoteichoic acid with a thick peptidoglycan layer is a feature of gram-positive bacteria. 

  Gram positive Gram negative
Teichoic acid, lipoteichoic acid Present Absent
Thickness (Peptidoglycan) Thicker Thinner
Variety of amino acids Few Several
Aromatic and sulfur-containing amino acids Absent Present
Lipopolysaccharides and outer membrane Absent Present

The cell wall of fungi consists of chitin, mannan, and polysaccharides (glucan). The cell wall of mycobacteria have mycolic acid, which is responsible for acid fastness.

questions.text: A baby was brought to the clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, failure to thrive, and hair loss. On examination, the following findings are noted. Identify the mineral deficiency leading to this condition.
questions.solution:
The clinical features shown in the images are periorificial dermatitis and alopecia. These features in a young child are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica seen with zinc deficiency.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a condition that occurs due to zinc deficiency and presents after weaning. Clinical features include failure to thrive, anorexia, diarrhea, recurrent infections, alopecia, male hypogonadism, and neurological manifestations like tremor, nystagmus, photophobia, hypogeusia, irritability, etc.

Skin manifestations such as vesiculobullous dermatitis on the extremities and periorificial(perianal, perigenital, perioral) regions are commonly seen as shown below. Affected infants require long-term supplementation with zinc.

Other options-

Option A- Niacin deficiency leads to Pellagra which is characterized by diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. Dermatitis is seen in sun-exposed areas and presents as hyperpigmentation around the neck known as Casal's necklace. An image of Casal's necklace is shown below.

Option C- Riboflavin deficiency manifests as glossitis, cheilitis, magenta-colored tongue, angular stomatitis, and circumcorneal vascularization as shown below.

Option D- Copper deficiency can present as anemia, cardiovascular defects including aneurysms, hypopigmentation, and neurological symptoms such as ataxia.

questions.text: All of the following are primary bile acids except?
questions.solution:
Deoxycholic acid is not a primary bile acid. It is a secondary bile acid.

The primary bile acids are cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid synthesised from cholesterol in the liver. They are next conjugated with glycine and taurine in the liver peroxisomes to form glycocholic, glycochenodeoxycholic, taurocholic, and taurochenodeoxycholic acids.

The secondary bile acids are formed in the intestine as they are deconjugated and dehydroxylated by the intestinal bacteria to form deoxycholic and lithocholic acid.

These are absorbed in the ileum and returned to the liver by enterohepatic circulation.

questions.text: The muscle marked by the arrow in the image below is innervated by the________.

choices.text: From the dorsal rami of C1

questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the above image is levator scapulae, which is innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve.

The appendicular group of back muscles and their innervations include:

Muscle  Nerve Supply

Trapezius

 Accessory nerve

Latissimus dorsi

 Thoracodorsal nerve

Levator scapulae

Rhomboid major and minor

 Dorsal scapular nerve

Option B: The suprascapular nerve innervates the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles.

Option D: The subscapular nerves supply the teres major and subscapularis muscles.

questions.text: What attaches at the 3' end of the transfer RNA (tRNA) cloverleaf structure?
questions.solution:
The sequence CCA attaches at the 3' end of the transfer RNA (tRNA) cloverleaf structure.

Transfer RNA is a type of RNA that helps to transport amino acids from the cell cytoplasm to the ribosome where protein synthesis is taking place. Since they are soluble in nature, they are also known as soluble RNA (sRNA). They undergo internal base-pairing (represented by the black dotted lines in the image below) to form the secondary cloverleaf structure.

Each part of the cloverleaf structure serves a different purpose. The parts of the cloverleaf include:

  • Anticodon loop
  • Acceptor arm
  • D loop
  • TΨC loop
  • Variable loop

 

The anticodon loop shown is where the anticodon triplet codons are present that make a tRNA specific. This anticodon will base pair with the complementary codon on the mRNA (messenger RNA) strand undergoing translation.

The acceptor arm is at the 3' end. This 3' end of the tRNA has the CCA sequence. The hydroxyl group on the A of the CCA sequence gets charged by accepting the amino acid specific to the codon (on the mRNA) that pairs with the anticodon loop. This then gets added to the elongating polypeptide chain. 

The D loop, TΨC loop, and variable loop are involved in defining the specific tRNA and ensuring accurate codon-anticodon base pairing.

Other options-

Option (A): The guanyl cap is not a part of tRNA. it is a molecule of 7-methyl guanosine triphosphate at the 5' end of mRNA. 

Option (B): The anticodon is present at the anticodon loop as shown in the above image. The anticodon is complementary to the codon present on the mRNA strand.

Option (D): The codon refers to sequences of base triplets on the mRNA strand. These codons base pair with the corresponding anticodons on the anticodon arm of the tRNA. This allows the correct amino acid at the 3' end of the tRNA structure to get added to the elongating polypeptide chain.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is not directly related to humerus?
questions.solution:
The median nerve is not directly related to the humerus.

 Nerves related to the humerus:

  • Axillary nerve is at the surgical neck 
  • Ulnar nerve is at the medial epicondyle
  • Radial nerve is at the spiral groove of the shaft of the humerus. 

 Median nerve course: 

  • Origin: Lateral and medial cords of the brachial plexus 
  • Axilla and arm: No muscle supply from the median nerve
  • Forearm (flexor compartment): It supplies most superficial flexors. It leaves the cubital fossa between the 2 heads of Pronator teres and gives off the anterior interosseous nerve
  • Before entering deep into the flexor retinaculum gives off a palmar cutaneous branch. At the distal end of the flexor retinaculum, it divides into a recurrent branch and palmar digital nerves

questions.text: The most common manifestation of MEN 1 syndrome involves _____.
questions.solution:
Primary hyperparathyroidism is the most common manifestation of Wermer’s syndrome or MEN-1 (80% to 95% of patients).

MEN 1 or Wermer syndrome.

  • Germline mutations in the MEN1 tumor-suppressor gene, which encodes a protein called menin.
  • Pancreatic polypeptide is the most commonly secreted product.
  • Most frequent anterior pituitary tumor encountered in MEN-1 is prolactinoma.
  • Duodenum is the most common site of gastrinomas in individuals with MEN-1.

questions.text: Magnesium does not have a role in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Magnesium has no role in copper metabolism.

Magnesium is a major intracellular cation required for the function of various enzymes such as hexokinase, phosphofructokinase, alkaline phosphatase, enolase, etc.

The role of magnesium can be seen in the following processes:

  • Calcium homeostasis: One-half of the total body magnesium is located in bone. Magnesium is important for PTH secretion which controls serum Ca2+ level.
  • Neuromuscular function: Hypomagnesemia may cause generalized alterations in neuromuscular function including tetany, tremor, seizures. Hypermagnesemia is known to cause symptoms of neuromuscular blockade such as hypoactive tendon reflexes, GI hypomotility, paralysis, etc
  • Maintenance of cardiac rhythm: Hypomagnesemia can lead to supraventricular and ventricular arrhythmias. Hypermagnesemia can cause bradycardia, heart block, and asystole.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not characteristic of pterygium?

choices.text: Abnormal activity of p53 is seen in the pterygium tissue.
Decreased activity of tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases is seen.
Destruction of Bowman's layer occurs when the pterygium invades the cornea.
Elastotic degeneration and hyalinization of the connective tissue of the conjunctiva occur.

questions.solution:
Elastotic degeneration and hyalinization of the conjunctival connective tissue occurs in pinguecula (and not pterygium). 

In pterygium, there is elastotic degeneration of collagen with fibrovascular proliferation.

It is important to distinguish a pterygium from a pinguecula. A pterygium, while histologically similar to a pinguecula, is distinguished by fibrovascular tissue that grows onto the cornea. Pingueculae do not have vascularized tissue and do not cross the limbus.

questions.text: Speedball refers to a combination of heroin with which drug?
questions.solution:
Coadministration of heroin with cocaine is known as 'speedball'. 

Coadministration of Phencyclidine and cocaine is known as 'beam me up'.

questions.text: A neonate is brought with complaints of photophobia and watering. Clinical examination shows normal tear passages and clear but large cornea. Investigation reveals Haab’s striae seen in the eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of buphthalmos. Haab’s striae are horizontal/circumferential breaks in Descemet’s membrane seen in buphthalmos.

Buphthalmos (Bull-like eyes) is an enlargement of the eyeball seen in true congenital and infantile glaucoma, usually when the disease onset is before 3 years.

The image given below shows Haab's striae and a child having buphthalmos in congenital glaucoma.

Note: 

Vogt's striae are vertical, fine, whitish lines (folds/tears) in Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.

The image given below shows Vogt's striae.

questions.text: Name the procedure depicted in the picture below.
questions.solution:
The picture depicts the nothern blotting technique.

Northern blotting is used for detection of RNA.

Other blotting techniques :

  • Southern blotting is used for detection of DNA.
  • Western blotting is used for detection of protein.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes the below condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows blackening of tongue.Colloidal bismuth subsalicylate is known to cause blackening of tongue, dentures, and stools.

It combines with trace amounts of sulfur in saliva and colon to form bismuth sulfide. Bismuth sulfide is a highly insoluble black salt.The adverse effects are temporary and harmless.

questions.text: How much is the inulin clearance?
questions.solution:
Inulin clearance is equal to 125 ml/ min. Since it is used for the measurement of GFR, inulin clearance will be equal to GFR, i.e 125 ml/min

Renal clearance is the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance by the kidneys per unit time. 

A higher renal clearance suggests the substance may be cleared almost completely in one pass through the kidneys while a low value describes a substance that may not be eliminated by the kidneys at all.

Clearance refers to the volume of plasma that would be necessary to supply the amount of substance excreted in the urine per unit of time. Stated mathematically,

Cx. Px = Ux. V

where Cx is the clearance rate of a substance x

Px is the plasma concentration of x

Ux is the urine concentration of that x

V is the urine flow rate

Rearranging this equation, clearance can be expressed as

questions.text: Identify the false statement about tests of eustachian tube function:

choices.text: Failure of Valsalva test proves that the tube is blocked
Politzer's test is done in children unable to perform Valsava test
Tympanometry causes both positive and negative pressure

questions.solution:
The false statement is 'failure of Valsalva test proves that the tube is blocked'. This is because only 65% of people can successfully perform this test. 

The Eustachian tube connects the nasopharynx with the tympanic cavity. The tympanic end is bony and is present in the anterior wall of the middle ear. The pharyngeal end is cartilaginous and is raised at the end called a torus tubaris, present in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx behind the posterior end of the inferior turbinate. 

The eustachian tube performs the following functions: 

  • Ventilation and regulation of middle ear pressure
  • Protection against nasopharyngeal sound pressure and reflux of nasopharyngeal secretions
  • Clearance of middle ear secretions. 

The eustachian tube function can be assessed with the following tests: 

Valsalva test this test builds positive pressure in the nasopharynx so the air enters the Eustachian tube. The patient pinches their nose, closes their mouth, and tries to blow air into their ears. If the air enters the middle ear, the tympanic membrane will move outwards which can be seen with the help of an otoscope or microscope. Failure of this test does not prove blockage because only 65% of people can successfully perform this test. 

It should be avoided in patients who have an atrophic scar or an active infection. 

Politzer's test is done in patients who are unable to perform Valsalva's test. Here, an olive-shaped tip of the Politzer's bag is introduced into the patient's nostril on the side where the tubal function is to be tested. The other nostril is closed while the bag is compressed at the same time the patient swallows. The examiner should hear a hissing sound through the auscultation tube if the tube is patent. 

Toynbee's test causes negative pressure. The patient is asked to swallow while the nose has been pinched. This maneuver draws air from the middle ear into the nasopharynx and causes inward movement of the tympanic membrane. The membrane movement is verified with an otoscope or microscope. 

Tympanometry or inflation-deflation test creates both positive and negative pressure in the external ear canal. The patient swallows repeatedly in this test. The ability of the tube to equilibrate positive and negative pressure to ambient pressure indicates normal tube function. It can be performed in patients with perforated or intact tympanic membranes. 

Other tests include catheterization, radiological test, saccharine or methylene blue test, and sonotubometry.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerve palsy is most common in nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
V cranial nerve palsy is the most common palsy seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma usually originates from the nasopharynx in the fossa of Rossenmuller. It is most commonly seen in Chinese people. 

Important etiological factors include Ebstein Barr virus (EBV) infection, tobacco smoking, dry salted fish, and incense fumes.

It presents with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal- Nasal obstruction due to blockage of the choana or the nasal cavity, denasal speech, nasal discharge, epistaxis.
  • Otologic- Obstruction of the eustachian tube leads to unilateral conductive hearing loss, serous or suppurative otitis media. 
  • Ophthalmologic- These symptoms occur due to the involvement of cranial nerves.
    • Facial pain and reduced corneal reflex- cranial nerve V. This is the most common cranial nerve to be involved.
    • Squint and diplopia- involvement of cranial nerve VI. 
    • Exophthalmos and blindness- cranial nerve II.
    • Horner's syndrome can occur due to involvement of sympathetic chain.
  • Cervical node metastasis- Usually between the angle of jaw and the mastoid. Cervical lymphadenopathy is the most common presenting symptom.
  • Distant metastasis- to bone, liver, lung, etc.
  • Constitutional symptoms - weight loss.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma can cause,

  • Conductive deafness (eustachian tube blockage),
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to involvement of CN V and
  • Palatal paralysis due to involvement of CN X

This is collectively called as Trotter’s triad.

Enlarged lateral retropharyngeal nodes compresses the cranial nerve IX, X, and XI causing jugular foramen syndrome.

High resolution contrast-enhanced CT (HR-CECT) of nose and nasopharynx is the investigation of choice.

The treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal carcinoma:

  • Radiotherapy for stages I and II.
  • Radiotherapy + chemotherapy for stages III and IV.
  • Radical neck dissection can be done in case of recurrent or residual disease.

Other options:

A) Involvement of VI cranial nerve leads to squint and diplopia.

B) Involvement of X cranial nerve leads to palatal paralysis

D) Involvement of IX cranial nerve forms a component of jugular foramen syndrome

questions.text: 500 mg of a drug was administered to a patient. 100 mg was cleared in 60 minutes. How much of the drug would be left in the body after 180  minutes if the excretion of the drug follows zero order kinetics?
questions.solution:
In zero order kinetics, a constant amount of drug is eliminated in unit time. 

In our question, 100 mg of drug is eliminated in 60 minutes (1 hour).

After 180 minutes (3 hours),

  • 3*100 = 300 mg would be eliminated.
  • 500-300 = 200 mg will be the remaining drug in the body.

questions.text: Roth spots are seen in ________.
questions.solution:
Roth's spots are seen in acute leukemia.

Roth's spots are retinal hemorrhages, named after Moritz Roth. It is a red spot (caused by hemorrhage), with a characteristic pale white center. This white center usually represents fibrin-platelet plugs.

They are composed of coagulated fibrin, including platelets, focal ischemia, inflammatory infiltrate, infectious organisms, or neoplastic cells.

Roth's spots may be seen in

  • Leukemia
  • Diabetes
  • Subacute bacterial endocarditis
  • Hypertensive retinopathy
  • HIV retinopathy
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus

Image: Roth's spots

questions.solution:
The eparterial bronchus supplies the right upper lobe, which includes the segments: apical, posterior and anterior.

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin​ shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA.

IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. Its serum levels are usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

When present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two additional polypeptides:

  • J chain, which stabilizes the molecule.
  • Secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the epithelial cell.

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: Which of the following is not increased in intravascular hemolysis?
questions.solution:
Haptoglobin is decreased in intravascular hemolysis.

Types of hemolysis based on location:

  • Intravascular hemolysis - hemolysis that occurs mainly within the blood vessels
  • Extravascular hemolysis - hemolysis that occurs via macrophages of the reticuloendothelial system in the spleen, liver, bone marrow, and lymph nodes

Features of intravascular hemolysis are:

  • Decreased haptoglobin
  • Increased lactate dehydrogenase 
  • Hemoglobinemia
  • Hemoglobinuria
  • Hemosiderinuria
  • Methemoglobinemia
  • Methemoglobinuria
  • Indirect hyperbilirubinemia

questions.text: Identify the sign seen in given X-ray.
questions.solution:
Orbital floor fracture also is known as the blowout fracture results in herniation of orbital contents into maxillary antrum, which is seen in X-Ray as teardrop sign.

Option B: Phlep’s sign is seen in CT scan in glomus jugulare tumor. It is the erosion of normal crest of bone between the carotid canal and jugular foramen.

Options C and D: Antral or Holman Miller sign are the same. Anterior bowing of the posterior wall of maxillary sinus often called antral sign or Holman-Miller sign is pathognomic of angiofibroma.

Holman miller sign in angiofibroma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of case-control studies?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, follow-up is not a part of case-control studies. 

Case-Control Studies are also called retrospective studies. This study proceeds from effect to cause and is done after the exposure and outcome have occurred. They focus on diseases or health problems that have already developed. They are less time-consuming and have no risk of attrition because they do not require follow-up.

There are four basic steps in conducting a case-control study:

  • Selection of cases and controls
  • Matching- This is done to ensure comparability between cases and controls. Controls are selected such that they are similar to cases with respect to certain pertinent selected variables that influence the disease outcome.
  • Measurement of exposure - This is obtained by interviews, questionnaires, or study of the past records of cases.
  • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio.

Odds Ratio (OR) calculated from a case-control study, is a measure of the strength of the association between risk factors and outcome.

Note: Follow-up is a part of cohort studies. The elements in cohort studies include selecting study subjects, obtaining data on exposure, selecting comparison groups, follow up and analysis.

questions.text: Which of these is an oncofetal antigen?
questions.solution:
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)

  • Valuable clinical aid in diagnosis, prognosis and monitoring primary hepatocellular carcinoma, hepatoblastoma, non-seminomatous testicular germ cell tumors, embryonal carcinoma, teratomas, choriocarcinoma, yolk sac carcinoma, germ cell tumors of the ovary and extragonadal germ cell tumors
  • Hepatoblastoma: an embryonic form has always been found to be associated with grossly elevated serum AFP levels.
  • Regenerated hepatic tissue following liver damage due to viral hepatitis, chemically induced necrosis, and liver surgery are associated with moderately raised serum AFP levels.

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)

  • Normally detected in glycocalyx of fetal epithelial cells
  • May play a role in the metastasis of cancer cells
  • CEA levels over 5 ng/dL: ascites fluid A/W malignancy
  • Detection, recurrence, and prognosis of adenocarcinoma (lung) and colorectal carcinoma
  • Elevated levels also present in cirrhosis, biliary obstruction, hepatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, smokers and post-surgical bowel sequestration with mucocele
  • Benign cysts may be CEA+ even when benign
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma: canalicular pattern for polyclonal CEA is 50-90% sensitive for hepatocellular carcinoma, > 95% specific
  • Pancreatic adenocarcinoma: 92% sensitive for metastases vs. 0% for bile duct adenoma.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about 'café coronary' syndrome is false?

choices.text: Mostly seen in well nourished businessmen
Autopsy often shows food, often steak, lodged in the pharynx or larynx
Death is due to mechanical asphyxia causing reflex cardiac inhibition
Death is often prolonged and happens hours later

questions.solution:
Death in 'café coronary' syndrome are sudden and unexpected and happen rapidly.

'Café coronary' syndrome:

  • In this syndrome, the victim dies suddenly and unexpectedly during a meal with no signs of respiratory distress or 'classical signs of asphyxia.
  • Initially thought to be coronary heart disease, autopsy revealed a bolus of food, often steak, lodged in the pharynx or larynx.
  • The cause of death in these patients is mechanical asphyxia leading to vasovagal reflex causing reflex cardiac inhibition.
  • The mode of death is clearly cardiac arrest (not the cause of death) presumably from parasympathetic overactivity occuring from stimulation of the laryngeal or pharyngeal mucosa.

questions.text: The term hidden hunger refers to _______

choices.text: Food shortage cause of by famines

questions.solution:
• Hidden hunger refers to micronutrient deficiency and it occurs when there is deficiency in intake or absorption of micronutrients like vitamins, iron, zinc, etc.
  • The health and development of a community are affected by less obvious or invisible effects of these deficiencies. Thus they are referred to as hidden hunger.
  • Consequences of hidden hunger are seen in all ages.

questions.text: Minimum inhibitory concentration can be calculated by all of the following except ________
questions.solution:
Minimum inhibitory concentration can be calculated by all except Kirby–Bauer test. MIC is the lowest concentration of an antimicrobial agent that will inhibit the visible growth of a microorganism.

Methods to determine MIC include:

  • Tube dilution method
  • Agar dilution method
  • E-test method

questions.text: Essential Fructosuria is due to deficiency of ______
questions.solution:
Essential Fructosuria is due to the deficiency of the enzyme hepatic Fructokinase, inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Fructokinase is the first enzyme to act on fructose metabolism.

  • This defective degradation does not cause any clinical symptoms.
  • Fructose is either excreted unchanged in the urine or metabolized to fructose-6-phosphate by alternate pathways in the body, most commonly by hexokinase in adipose tissue and muscle.
  • No treatment is indicated for essential fructosuria.

questions.text: The process designed to prevent microorganisms from reaching a protected environment is called _______
questions.solution:
• Asepsis is the process by which microorganisms are prevented from reaching an area that is free from them. This applies methods of sterilization and disinfection to create a protective environment.
  • Sterilization is the killing or removal of all living and viable forms of a microorganism from an area or surface.
  • Disinfection is the process by which disruption and destruction of microorganisms is achieved with the use of physical or chemical agents, to varying degrees of efficacy. Microbial forms like spores and some viruses may be resistant to certain disinfectants.
  • Pasteurization is a form of disinfection in which sufficient heat is used to destroy pathogenic organisms in liquids like milk or water.

questions.text: All are features of exercise except _______

choices.text: Left shift of Hb-O2 dissociation curve
Increase in blood supply to muscle

questions.solution:
During exercise, several factors shift the dissociation curve considerably to the right, thus delivering extra amounts of O2 to the active, exercising muscle fibers.

The right shift of Hb-O2 dissociation curve is due to the following:

  • Release of large quantities of CO2 by the exercising muscles
  • Increase in the hydrogen ion concentration in the muscle capillary blood 
  • Increase in the temperature of the muscle by 2° to 3°C

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is diagnosed with carcinoma limited to the glottis of the larynx. Which of the following lymph nodes would be initially involved?
questions.solution:
Tumours limited to the glottis usually do not spread to any lymph node station as there are no lymphatics in the vocal cords.

However, if the tumour invades the supra- or the infra- glottic spaces, lymph node spread can occur. 

Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumour of the larynx. Glottis is the most common site of cancer.

questions.text: A patient requires the shortest acting formulation of insulin to prevent postprandial hyperglycemia. Which of the following formulations would you choose?
questions.solution:
Inhaled insulin is the shortest acting formulation of insulin.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of facial puffiness and frothy urine. Given below is the histological image of the condition. What do you think is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall(intense pink) characteristic of membranous nephropathy.

Membranous nephropathy is one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome. It is a form of chronic immune-complex-mediated disease.

  • Light microscopy: Diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall without cellular proliferation. Irregular spikes projecting from the basement membrane are best seen with silver stains.
  • Immunofluorescence microscopy: granular deposits containing Ig and complement along the glomerular basement membrane
  • Electron micrograph: electron-dense subepithelial deposits (epi membranous spikes) and effacement of foot processes of podocytes
The silver stain of the glomerulus highlights the proteinaceous basement membranes in black. There are characteristic "spikes" of the basement membrane between the immune deposits of membranous nephropathy. The black basement membrane material shown here appears as projections in the capillary loops.

questions.text: Case detection in STDs is done by all except_______
questions.solution:
Notification is not a part of the case detection of STDs.

Case detection in STDs includes all of the following methods:

  • Screening
  • Contact tracing
  • Cluster testing

questions.text: The milk ring test is found to be positive for a sample of milk. Which organism has it most likely been contaminated with?
questions.solution:
Milk ring test (MRT) is positive for Brucella. It is used for the detection of infected animals in dairy farms. 

A sample of whole milk is mixed with a drop of Brucella antigen and incubated at 70 °C for 40–50 min.

If antibodies are present in the milk, the bacilli are agglutinated and rise with the cream to form a blue ring at the top, leaving the rest of the milk unstained (MRT positive). If antibodies are absent, the solution remains uniformly blue (MRT negative).

questions.text: Fat-soluble vitamin with a coenzyme activity is ______
questions.solution:
The only fat-soluble vitamin that has a coenzyme function is vitamin K.

The co-enzyme role of vitamin K is in the γ-carboxylation reaction of clotting factors.

Many of the water-soluble vitamins also have a coenzyme function, i.e., vitamin B1 as thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), vitamin B6 as pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), etc.

questions.text: The middle meningeal artery enters into the middle cranial fossa through which of the following foramina?
questions.solution:
The middle meningeal artery enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen spinosum, labelled as 3 in the image.

Foramina marked in the image are

1 - Foramen rotundum

2 - Foramen ovale

3 - Foramen spinosum

4 - Jugular foramen

The middle meningeal artery is a branch of the first part of maxillary artery, given off in the infratemporal fossa. In here it first runs upwards and medially between the sphenomandibular ligament and lateral pterygoid muscle and then passes through a loop formed by the two roots of the auriculotemporal nerve.
Following this, it enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen spinosum; following which it has an extradural course. It runs forward and laterally, grooving the squamous temporal bone and gives rise to its frontal and parietal branches.

The middle meningeal artery is predominantly a periosteal artery which supplies the bone and red bone marrow in the diploe.

questions.text: A 9-month-old baby was brought with complaints of loose stools for 2 weeks. Which of the following organisms is likely to cause this disease?
questions.solution:
Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) causes infantile bacterial diarrhea. It is nontoxigenic and noninvasive.

E. coli is the second most common cause of diarrhea in the pediatric age group. Rotavirus is the most common cause. EPEC causes persistent watery diarrhea which is self-limiting.

EPEC adheres to the mucosal cells of the small bowel and causes loss of microvilli (effacement). This leads to formation of filamentous actin pedestals or cuplike structures and occasionally may cause entry of the EPEC into the mucosal cells.

Pathogenicity requires the presence of two important factors:

  •  Bundle forming pilus encoded by plasmid containing EPEC adherence factor (EAF).
  •  Chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenecity island.

Other options:

Option B: Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC) produce two potent toxins, verocytotoxin (VT) or Shiga-like toxin (SLT). Especially in young children and the elderly, they cause diarrhea ranging from mild to fatal hemorrhagic colitis and hemorrhagic uremic syndrome (HUS). EHEC primarily targets vascular endothelial cells leading to HUS. E.coli serotype 0157: H7 is associated with EHEC diarrhea and its complications.

Option C: Enterotoxigenic E. coli causes endemic diarrhoea in developing countries and travellers diarrhoea. ETEC serotypes responsible for diarrhea are mostly 06, 08, 015, 025, 027, 0167. It attaches to intestinal mucosa with fimbriae called colonization factor antigens. The pathology is due to the heat-labile toxin (LT) produced by some and heat-stable toxin (ST) produced by others.

Option D: Enteroinvasive E.coli (EIEC) has clinical features are similar to shigellosis. It produces disease by invading the intestinal mucosa.

questions.text: Condition favourable for adipocere formation is _________

choices.text: Hot weather and dry air currents

questions.solution:
Warm and humid weather is a favourable condition for adipocere formation.

Prerequisites for adipocere formation:

  • Abundant fat
  • Moisture
  • Still air
  • Warm temperature
  • Bacteria producing fat splitting enzyme like Clostridium welchii

questions.text: The first urge to defecate occurs when rectal pressure is increased to:
questions.solution:
The first urge to defecate occurs when rectal pressure is increased to 18 mm Hg.

When this pressure reaches 55 mm Hg, the external and the internal sphinc­ter relax, and there is reflex expulsion of the contents of the rectum.

Defecation reflex: Distension of the rectum and colon stimulates stretch receptors in the rectal wall. Then, the defecation reflexes travel from the colon and rectum to the spinal cord and back again to produce the powerful colonic, rectal, and abdominal contractions required for defecation.

questions.text: Which of the following is an antimetabolite?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate is an antimetabolite. It is a folic acid analog that inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). Methotrexate and its polyglutamate also inhibit the enzymes involved in denovo purine and thymidylate synthesis.

questions.text: Formation of which of the following indicates the beginning of gastrulation?
questions.solution:
The formation of the primitive streak from the epiblast is an indicator of the beginning of gastrulation. 

By the 15th day of development, some epiblast cells lying along the central axis, near the tail end of the embryonic disc, begin to proliferate. These proliferated cells form an elevation called primitive streak that bulges into the amniotic cavity. 

Gastrulation is the process that forms all the 3 germ layers namely, ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm in the embryo. It occurs during the 3rd week of gestation.

The image given below shows the formation of primitive streak.

questions.text: Cytochrome oxidase is inhibited in all of the following poisonings except:
questions.solution:
Cytochrome oxidase is a hemoprotein, which is the terminal component of the respiratory chain carriers (complex IV) in mitochondria. The action of cytochrome oxidase is inhibited in carbon monoxide, cyanide, and hydrogen sulfide poisoning, resulting in prevention of cellular respiration.

Hemoproteins are metalloproteins that have a typical heme prosthetic group. They are present in myoglobin, hemoglobin, and other cytochromes. Cytochrome oxidase contains two molecules of heme, each having one Fe atom that oscillates between Fe3+ and Fe2+ during oxidation and reduction. It also contains two atoms of copper, each associated with a heme unit.

Complexes  of ETC  :

Complex I: NADH-CoQ oxidoreductase

Contains - FeS, FMN, Coenzyme Q

Inhibitors – Rotenone

Complex II: Succinate-CoQ reductase

Contains - FeS, Coenzyme Q

Inhibitor - Carboxin

Complex III: CoQH2-cytochrome c oxidoreductase

Contains - cytochrome c, b, C1, and FeS

Inhibitor - Antimycin A

Complex IV: cytochrome oxidase

Contains - Cytochrome a, a3, and Copper

Inhibitor - Cyanide, Azide, Carbon monoxide

Complex V (informally): ATP Synthase

Inhibitor - Oligomycin

Note: MELAS (mitochondrial encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke) is an inherited condition due to NADH-Q oxidoreductase (Complex I) or cytochrome oxidase (Complex IV) deficiency.

questions.text: A newborn baby was brought to the OPD with complaints of refusal of feeds. According to IMNCI, how would you triage this patient?
questions.solution:
Newborn babies presenting with refusal of feeds must be admitted to special newborn care units (SNCU). 

According to the facility-based newborn care set up by the IMNCI, SNCU are set up in district hospitals and a few sub-district hospitals where there are more than 3000 deliveries per year.

Neonates undergo quick screening for signs which help sort sick neonates according to emergency, priority, and non-urgent. Triage of sick newborn is done according to the signs observed as follows:

Facility-based newborn care:

The IMNCI has set up SNCUs at district hospitals, stabilization units at CHCs, and newborn care corners at all facilities offering delivery facilities to equip these facilities to provide the requisite level of care and simultaneously enhancing the capacity of the medical officers at these facilities to handle cases of sick newborn and children. The facilities available at different levels of Newborn Care Centers are as follows:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a primary endpoint in phase 1 studies?
questions.solution:
Efficacy is not a primary endpoint in phase 1 studies. Phase 1 studies are generally done in healthy volunteers. Efficacy can be a secondary endpoint in some studies where patients are recruited.

The primary endpoints are:

  • Safety
  • Tolerability of single/multiple doses
  • Pharmacokinetic parameters 

The primary endpoint denotes the purpose of the study for which it is primarily designed. The secondary endpoint denotes the measure of the valuable outcome of the study design.

questions.text: The type of personality which is more at risk of developing coronary heart disease is ______
questions.solution:
Type A behavior is associated with competitive drive, restlessness, hostility and a sense of urgency and impatience. Hence, type A individuals are more prone to CHD stroke and peripheral vascular diseases.

Type A behavior: competitive, ambitious, impatient, aggressive, fast-talking.

Type B behavior more relaxed, less neurotic, frantic, explainable.

Type C behavior has difficulty expressing emotion and tends to suppress emotions, particularly negative ones such as anger.

questions.text: Which of the following pathway is the most important source of reducing equivalents for fatty acid synthesis in the liver?
questions.solution:
The most important source of reducing equivalents (NADPH) for fatty acid synthesis in the liver is the hexose monophosphate shunt pathway (HMP).

Since HMP shunt pathway and fatty acid synthesis both occur in the cytosol of the cell, there are no membranes or permeability barriers against the transfer of NADPH. This NADPH is involved as a donor of reducing equivalents in both the reduction of the 3-ketoacyl and of the 2,3-unsaturated acyl derivatives. 

Other sources are:

  • Extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase (minor source)
  • Malic enzyme

questions.text: Insulin inhibits which of the following lipase enzymes?
questions.solution:
Insulin has an inhibitory effect on lipolytic hormones like hormone sensitive lipase (HSL). In adipose tissues, the stored triglycerides are broken down (lipolysis) by hormone sensitive lipase (HSL) into free fatty acids (FFAs). Insulin inhibits HSL and thus reduces the release of FFAs and also glycerol.

In diabetic patients, low insulin level corresponds to an increase in HSL activity, promoting the breakdown of lipids and release of FFAs from adipose tissue. Hormone-sensitive lipase activity is accelerated by hormones like epinephrine, norepinephrine, glucagon, ACTH, TSH, GH, ADH, and Melanocyte stimulating hormones (MSH).

Insulin induces the activity of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) which is present on the walls of capillaries. LPL promotes hydrolysis of TGs and degradation of VLDL and chylomicrons. In diabetes, low insulin leads to decreased LPL activity resulting in increased VLDL and TGs levels.

Well-fed state (Insulin) During fasting (Glucagon)
Lipogenesis increased Lipogenesis inhibited
Lipolysis inhibited Lipolysis increased
Insulin inhibits HS-lipase Glucagon activates HS-lipase
Lipoprotein lipase active Lipoprotein lipase inactive
