questions.text: Interstitial fluid volume is best measured using a combination of which two dyes?
questions.solution:
Interstitial fluid volume is best measured using a combination of inulin and Evans blue.

Inulin is a marker that distributes uniformly throughout the extracellular fluid, including the interstitial fluid, while Evans blue remains confined to the intravascular space. By using both dyes, one can measure the total extracellular fluid volume with inulin and the intravascular volume with Evans blue, allowing for the calculation of interstitial fluid volume.

Insterstitial fluid is measured indirectly. Interstitial fluid volume= ECF - plasma volume.

  • Best measure of ECF: Inulin
  • Best measure of Plasma Volume: Evans Blue (T1824)

questions.text: An example of disability limitation is ____.
questions.solution:
• Spectacles for a refractive error would be disability limitation.
  • DOTS would be secondary prevention as it is part of a treatment.
  • BCG vaccine and cessation of smoking are forms of primary prevention.
  • Refractive errors are disabilities and spectacles do not cure them.
  • Thus, spectacles would be tertiary prevention as it limits the effect of refractory errors on a person.

questions.text:
Which of the following increases in COPD?
  1. FRC
  2. TLC
  3. VC
  4. FEV1/FVC
questions.solution:
In COPD, the functional residual capacity increases. Total lung capacity may be increased or normal. Hence, both 1 and 2 are correct. In obstructive lung diseases:

  • Both FEV1 and FVC reduces, where the decrease in FEV1 is more than the reduction in FVC. As a result, the ratio of FEV1/FVC also decreases.
  • The total lung capacity is usually normal in chronic bronchitis, while increased in emphysema.
  • Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is increased in COPD
     

Lung Capacities:

The total lung capacity can be broken down into alternative capacities that help to define functioning lungs.

  • The vital lung capacity refers to the maximum amount of air expired from the fully inflated lung or maximum inspiratory level.
  • The inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level.
  • The functional residual capacity represents the volume of the air remaining in the lungs after expiration of a normal breath. Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is expiratory reserve volume + residual volume.

questions.text: Two days after penicillin administration, a patient developed antibodies that resulted in hemolysis. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
Development of antibodies resulting in hemolysis after penicillin administration is an example of a type II reaction. This is a drug-induced type II hypersensitivity reaction.

Penicillin in high doses can result in immune-mediated hemolysis via the hapten mechanism. In this, the drug attaches to surface of RBC membrane. Antibodies are produced that are targeted against this combination of penicillin and RBCs. 

Complement is activated by the attached antibody leading to the removal of red blood cells by the spleen.

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersensitivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: Saccule in larynx is an extension of_____
questions.solution:
Ventricle (sinus of larynx):

  • It is a deep elliptical space between vestibular and vocal folds.
  • The saccule is a diverticulum of mucous membrane which starts from the anterior part of ventricular cavity and extends upwards between vestibular folds and lamina of thyroid
  • When abnormally enlarged and distended, it may form a Laryngocele - an air containing sac which may present in the neck.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient is referred to a dermatologist for evaluation of vesicles and bullae and increased pigmentation over sun-exposed areas such as the dorsal hands and forearms, legs and feet, neck and face. On further evaluation, she is diagnosed with variegate porphyria. This condition is caused due to deficiency of the enzyme:
questions.solution:
This condition is caused due to the deficiency of the enzyme protoporphyrinogen oxidase.

Variegate porphyria is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a mutation in the PPOX gene, which results in either the deficiency of or decreased function of the enzyme protoporphyrinogen oxidase.

questions.text: A 20 year old woman from Karnataka presents with fever, severe myalgia and arthralgia, pain behind the eyes and rash for 3 days. Lab reports show thrombocytopenia and leucopenia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is dengue. Dengue presents as sudden-onset fever, retroorbital pain, muscle and joint pains, and a rash. Thrombocytopenia is an important finding in dengue infection. The alternative name for dengue, "breakbone fever", comes from the associated muscle and joint pains. 

The three phases of dengue include febrile, critical, and recovery. 

  • Febrile phase has fever, facial flushing, skin erythema with macular rash, myalgias, arthralgias, headache, sore throat, conjunctival injection, anorexia, nausea, and vomiting.
  • Critical phase is associated with increased capillary permeability, rapid decline in platelet count, rise in hematocrit and the presence of warning signs. It can progress to shock, organ dysfunction, disseminated intravascular coagulation, or hemorrhage.
  • Recovery phase entails the gradual reabsorption of extravascular fluid.

The image below shows the erythema with petechiae of a patient with dengue fever. (White islands in a red sea)

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with painful swelling in the middle finger around the proximal phalanx. X-ray  is as seen in the image below. The growth has heterozygous mutations in the IDH1 and IDH2 genes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is enchondroma.

Enchondromas are intraosseous benign, lobulated tumours of hyaline cartilage. They are usually solitary, central, metaphyseal lesions of tubular bones, which usually affect the small bones of the hand and feet followed by the femur and humerus. Enchondromatous tumours typically begin and grow in childhood arising from rests of growth plate cartilage or chondrocytes that proliferate and enlarge, then stop growing but remain present throughout adulthood. Enchondromas can transform into chondrosarcoma. 

They are associated with mutations in isocitrate dehydrogenase-1 (IDH1) and 2 (IDH2) genes.  

Microscopically, enchondromas appear as grey-blue, translucent, hypocellular, non-vascular tumors with abundant hyaline cartilage. The nuclei of these cells are regular with few mitotic figures.

Diagnosis of enchondromas requires histopathologic examination, which shows punctate calcifications of the chondroid matrix and is composed of well-circumscribed nodules of benign hyaline cartilage. The nuclei of the chondrocytes are small and uniformly round with condensed chromatin.

Other options:

Option A: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignancy of bone that produces osteoid matrix or mineralized bone.  X-ray shows periosteal reaction and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance as shown below.


Option B: Ewing's sarcoma is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after osteosarcoma. Onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is seen on radiology (as shown below) and Homer-Wright rosettes, which are round groupings of cells with a central fibrillary core may be seen histologically.


Option C: Osteoclastoma is also called a giant cell tumour because multinucleated osteoclast-type giant cells are present on histology. The image below shows an X-ray of a giant cell tumor showing an eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis and the typical soap bubble appearance

questions.text: A patient presents with a platelet count of 700 x 10∧9/L with peripheral smear as shown below. WBC count of 12 x 10∧9/L, hemoglobin of 11 g/dL and the absence of Philadelphia chromosome. The most likely diagnosis would be______.
questions.solution:
The results of the laboratory investigations and peripheral smear are suggestive of essential thrombocythemia (ET).

WHO ET criteria

Major criteria

Platelet count ≥450 × 10 9/L

Bone marrow biopsy showing proliferation of enlarged, mature megakaryocytes with hyperlobulated nuclei.

Not meeting WHO criteria for BCR-ABL1 CML, ML, PV, PMF, myelodysplastic syndromes, or other myeloid neoplasms

Presence of JAK2, CALR, or MPL mutation

Minor criterion

Presence of a clonal marker or absence of evidence for reactive thrombocytosis

Diagnosis of ET requires meeting all 4 major criteria or the first 3 major criteria and the minor criterion

 

Normal values per litre:

  • Total leukocytes: 4.00–11.0 x 10 9/L
  • Platelet count: 150–400 x 109/L

questions.text: Identify the surgical step given in the image below.
questions.solution:
Capsulorrhexis is the step shown in the given image.

Capsulorrhexis is a method of anterior capsulotomy, where an opening is made in the anterior capsule of the lens. It is one of the steps involved in conventional extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE).

Continuous Curvilinear Capsulorrhexis (CCC), is considered to be superior to all the preexisting methods because when done correctly, it does not leave any edges or tears. Trypan blue dye can be used to stain the lens capsule for better visibility.

In ECCE, a portion of the anterior capsule of the lens is removed, allowing extraction of the lens nucleus and cortex. This leaves the remainder of the anterior capsule, the posterior capsule, and the zonular support intact. The intact lens nucleus is then removed from the eye through a limbal incision. 

An anterior capsulotomy is followed by hydro dissection using a balanced salt solution. This helps to separate the corticonuclear mass from the capsule. Removal of lens nucleus and aspiration of the cortex is done using a two-way irrigation and aspiration cannula. An intraocular lens (IOL) is then implanted and the incision is then closed.

Some of the IOLs used are shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the hospital in a semi-conscious state. He is sweating profusely, has muscle weakness, breathlessness with an audible wheeze and constricted pupils. On further evaluation, he is diagnosed with carbaryl poisoning. Which of the following should not be used for treatment?
questions.solution:
Pralidoxime should not be used for treatment.

Pralidoxime may be hazardous in poisoning with carbaryl, which is a carbamate insecticide. It is not effective in carbamate anti-ChE poisoning as the anionic site required for attachment of oximes is occupied. 

Oximes are usually contraindicated in carbamate poisoning, as they do not reactivate the enzyme. They also have anti-ChE activity of their own that may worsen the condition.  

Option B: Atropine is the mainstay in the management of carbamate poisoning. 

Options C and D: Diazepam may be used for the management of seizures. Activated charcoal can be used to perform gastric lavage in oral carbamate poisoning.

questions.text: A patient who suffers from periodic fevers is said to have a mutation in a gene for Pyrin, a protein that is predominantly found in which of the following cells?
questions.solution: Pyrin, the protein that is implicated in periodic fevers, is mainly found in Neutrophils.

questions.solution:
Emeiocytosis requires Ca2+ directly.

Emeiocytosis includes: movement of secretory granules to the plasma membrane of the cell-> fusion of the granule surface membrane with the cell membrane-> rupture of membranes-> liberation of granular contents into the pericapillary space. 

Insulin is secreted via the process of emeiocytosis (as shown in the image below)

It is promoted by Ca2+,  ↑ K+

It is inhibited by Mg2+, K+ depletion.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the multilayered epithelium that consists of deeper columnar cells and a surface layer of flat cells?
questions.solution:
The multilayered epithelium that consists of deeper columnar cells and a surface layer of flat cells is known as the stratified squamous epithelium.

Stratified (multi-layered) epithelia are of the following types:

  1. Stratified squamous epithelium:
    • The deepest layer is usually columnar, above which there are layers of cuboidal cells, and as it proceeds towards the surface of the epithelium the cells become increasingly flattened (or squamous).
    • It is further classified into keratinized and non-keratinized epithelium.
  2. Stratified cuboidal/columnar epithelium:
    • It consists of two or more layers of cuboidal or columnar cells, respectively.
  3. Transitional epithelium:
    • It is a specialized epithelium lining most of the urinary tract; hence, it is also called urothelium. 
    • The deepest layer consists of columnar or cuboidal cells, and the middle layer consists of polyhedral or pear-shaped cells.
    • The surface layer consists of large, polypoid, dome-shaped or umbrella-shaped cells. As the epithelium gets stretched to accommodate urine, the surface cells become flattened. 
    • The cells are called transitional due to this apparent change (transition) from stratified cuboidal epithelium in a relaxed state to stratified squamous epithelium when it is stretched.

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: Which of the following is not one of the mechanisms in the pathogenesis of edema?
questions.solution:
Increased plasma colloid osmotic pressure is not one of the mechanisms in the pathogenesis of edema. 

Edema is the accumulation of tissue fluid in the extracellular space, resulting from hemodynamic changes in the body. Normally, the outward hydrostatic pressure in the blood vessels is balanced by the inward pull of the colloid osmotic pressure exerted by plasma proteins. Any remaining fluid in the interstitial space is usually drained by the lymphatics into the thoracic duct, and thereby, back into the bloodstream. 

Edema results when there is an abnormality in any of these balancing forces. In heart failure, there is increased hydrostatic pressure in the venous system due to the inability of the heart to pump blood. This can result in edema which usually begins in the lower extremities.

In liver disease, there is a failure to synthesize adequate amounts of plasma proteins. On the other hand, in nephrotic disease of the kidney, there is excessive excretion of plasma proteins. Both of these conditions can result in decreased plasma colloid osmotic pressure. This normally acts as an inward pull on fluid from the interstitial spaces into the blood vessels.

Another mechanism of edema is in the setting of acute inflammation when there is increased vessel permeability, leading to fluid leaks into the interstitium.

Lymphatic obstruction due to infection or malignant infiltration can stop the normal tissue fluid drainage which results in fluid accumulation.

Renal failure is another cause of edema, which occurs due to the retention of sodium and water in large amounts, which ultimately increase the hydrostatic pressure within the vessels as mentioned above.

questions.text: Mepolizumab is approved for use in severe asthma. The drug is a monoclonal antibody against:
questions.solution:
Mepolizumab is a monoclonal antibody against IL-5.

IL-5 plays a pivotal role in eosinophilic inflammation and is also involved in eosinophil survival and priming.

Mepolizumab is approved in highly selected (eosinophilic phenotype) patients with severe asthma.

Monoclonal antibodies against IL-5 approved for asthma are:

  • Mepolizumab
  • Reslizumab
  • Benralizumab

questions.text: Photostress test is used to differentiate between:
questions.solution:
Photostress test is used to differentiate between the disease involving the macula and optic nerve.

In this test, one eye is covered and the patient is asked to read the smallest line on the near chart. A bright light is then shone into the eye for 15 seconds, and the patient is asked to read the line again, and the time taken to recover is noted. The test is repeated with the other eye.

In normal persons and in patients with optic nerve disease, the recovery time is not affected. Whereas, in patients with macular disease the recovery time is prolonged and is usually more than one-third of the normal recovery time. This is because, in macular disease, the photoreceptors are damaged, and there is a delay in the visual pigment regeneration process.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old race car champion is brought by his manager to the ENT surgeon for the correction of the condition shown below, which occurred after sustaining a blow to the face by the runner-up two months prior. The driver is asymptomatic and is scheduled to undergo an SMR operation. Identify the false statement about this procedure.

SMR - Submucous Resection of Nasal Septum

choices.text: Most of the bone and cartilage are preserved
Not done before the age of 17 years
Periosteal flaps raised on both sides of septum
Greater chance of complications compared to septoplasty

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with an image showing the midline deviation of the dorsum of the nose is indicative of a deviated nasal septum (DNS). The false statement about the SMR (submucous resection of nasal septum) procedure is that most of the bone and cartilage are preserved.

DNS is an important cause of nasal obstruction. It is associated with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal obstruction
  • Chronic sinusitis
  • Headache
  • Epistaxis
  • Anosmia
  • External deformity. 

The indications for an SMR are:

  • DNS causing symptoms of nasal obstruction and recurrent headaches.
  • DNS obstructing paranasal sinuses and middle ear, resulting in recurrent sinusitis and otitis media.
  • Recurrent epistaxis from a septal spur.
  • As a part of septorhinoplasty, for cosmetic correction of external nasal deformities.
  • As a preliminary step in hypophysectomy or Vidian neurectomy.

It is contraindicated in children below 17 years of age (Option B), during acute respiratory infection, bleeding diathesis, untreated diabetes, or hypertension.

In this procedure, mucoperichondrial and mucoperiosteal flaps are raised on both sides of the septum (Option C). Bony and cartilaginous parts of the septum are excised. This is followed by extensive dissection of the septum removing all deformed bony and cartilaginous parts of the septum and preserving only a caudal and a dorsal strut of cartilage.

Re-operating following an SMR is difficult compared to a septoplasty, which involves fewer complications and an easier re-operation. (Option D)

questions.text: In Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON), the defect is______.
questions.solution:
In Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON), the defect is a mutation of maternal mitochondrial DNA. Therefore maternal inheritance. 

Clinical features:

  • It typically affects males between the ages of 15 and 35 years.
  • It causes bilateral, subacute painless loss of vision.
  • Pupillary light reflex is relatively preserved until the late stage of disease.
  • Optic neuritis in one eye is followed by involvement of the other eye.
  • Optic atrophy in one eye is followed by involvement of the other eye
  • Centrocaecal scotoma
  • The diagnosis of LHON should be considered in any patient with bilateral optic neuropathy, irrespective of age.
  • LHON plus refers to rare variants with additional manifestations such as neuromuscular dysfunction.
  • Prognosis is poor, although some visual recovery may occur in a minority of cases even years later.
  • The condition cannot be controlled by drugs since it is genetically controlled.

questions.text: The type of potentiation in hippocampus is ______
questions.solution:
Long-term potentiation (LTP) occurs in the hippocampus.

  • Long-term Potentiation (LTP)
    • A rapidly developing persistent enhancement of the post-synaptic potential response to presynaptic stimulation, after rapidly repeated stimulation of presynaptic neuron
    • Characteristically observed in the hippocampus
    • NMDA receptors are involved in LTP.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with complaints of a weak urine stream and frequent urination in small amounts for the past month. He also mentions that he often feels lightheaded and has low blood pressure. Which of the following alpha-blockers will you prefer to give him?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and tamsulosin should be given to this patient as it has the least effect on blood pressure. 

It is an α-blocker that has more selectivity towards α1A/1D when compared to α1B receptors. The vasodilatory effects are mainly attributed to the blockade of α1B receptors present on blood vessels.

The relief of BPH symptoms is mainly due to the blockade of α1A receptors present predominantly in the prostatic stroma. It lacks the apoptotic effect on prostatic cells that is seen with terazosin and doxazosin.

questions.text: What type of joint is an incudostapedial joint?
questions.solution:
The incudostapedial joint is a ball and socket type of joint.

In ball and socket type of joints, the articular surfaces include a globular head (male surface) fitting into a cup-shaped socket (female surface). These joints are multi-axial and movements occur around a number of axes. Flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, medial rotation, lateral rotation, and circumduction, all occur quite freely. E.g., shoulder joint, hip joint, talocalcaneonavicular joint, and incudostapedial joint.

Note: The other joint between the incus and malleus (incudomalleolar joint) is a saddle joint. 

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: An elderly tuberculosis patient on treatment is non-compliant to initial therapy. Drug susceptibility showed resistance to rifampicin and isoniazid. He was started with the next-line drug that inhibits mycobacterial ATP synthesis. Which of the following can be the newly given drug?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the drug that inhibits mycobacterial ATP synthesis is bedaquiline.

Bedaquiline targets subunit c of the ATP synthase of M. tuberculosis. This results in inhibition of the proton pump activity of the ATP synthase and causes a failure in the bacillary energy metabolism.

Regimen for MDR TB:

400 mg daily for 2 weeks followed by 200 mg three times a day thereafter.

Other options:

Option A: Cycloserine inhibits alanine racemase that converts L-alanine to D-alanine. This stops the reactions in which D-alanine is incorporated into mycobacterial bacterial cell wall synthesis. 

Option B: Ethioinamide inhibits mycobacterial growth by inhibiting the activity of the enoyl-ACP reductase of fatty acid synthase II which is an inhA gene product. Isoniazid inhibits the same enzyme. 

Option D- Pretomanid is used in extensively drug-resistant and multi-drug-resistant TB. It inhibits mycolic acids and proteins synthesis of M. tuberculosis and in non-replicating persistent bacilli, they create reactive nitrogen species which then increases the killing of the bacterium by innate immunity.

questions.text: A patient presented with yawning, feeling of anxiety, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, increased sweating, and secretions from the eyes and nose were noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of opioid withdrawal. 

The features of opioid withdrawal are:

  • Feeling of anxiety
  • Yawning
  • Lacrimation, diaphoresis, rhinorrhea
  • Diffuse myalgias progressing to piloerection
  • Mydriasis
  • Nausea, profuse vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal cramping

Treatment of opioid withdrawal:

  • Symptoms can be rendered more tolerable by the administration of the central α2-agonist like clonidine
  • Antiemetics and antidiarrheal agents
  • Daily administration of a verified dose of methadone PO is recommended to inhibit withdrawal symptoms and reduce craving

questions.text: Which of the following fractures results most commonly due to falling from a height onto the feet?
questions.solution:
Ring fracture - These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum and are most often caused by a fall from height. If the kinetic energy of the fall is not absorbed by fractures of the legs, pelvis or spine, the impact is transmitted up the cervical spine. This may be rammed into the skull, carrying a circle of occipital bone with it.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture - Separation of sutures due to blow with blunt weapon or from cerebral edema. It is also called sutural fracture.

Fissured fracture/Linear fracture:

  • Linear skull fractures are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture - Occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. It is also known as indented fracture.

Depressed fracture - Caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced. So it is also called 'signature fracture'.

Comminuted fracture - It is also called spider web fracture and has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of fracture.

questions.text: The term 'choking' as understood in ballistics, applies to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Choking is a modification applied to the barrel of a shotgun.

Choke - This is where the barrel is modified such that it slightly tapers towards the muzzle. This will produce a narrower cone of shot, when the ammunition is fired and thus, prevent dispersion of pellets. This can thus affect estimation of range of firing when examining the entry wound. 

Types of choking:

  • Improved cylinder
  • Modified choke
  • Half-choke
  • Full-choke

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic difference between a typical cervical and thoracic vertebra?

choices.text: Cervical vertebrae have longer spinous processes
Thoracic vertebrae  foramina are bigger than the body
Thoracic vertebrae have turbercles on transverse processes

questions.solution:
The typical cervical vertebrae are characterized by a foramen in the transverse process called the foramen transversarium. 

This foramen transversarium transmits the vertebral artery and vein, along with a branch from the cervicothoracic ganglion (vertebral nerve). Lateral parts of the transverse processes of the cervical vertebrae also contain the anterior and posterior tubercles.

Feature Typical cervical vertebrae Typical thoracic vertebrae
Vertebral body Smaller and thinner

Intermediate in size between cervical and lumbar

Costal facets for the ribs seen on either the vertebral body, the transverse process, or both
Vertebral foramina Larger and wider than the vertebral body Smaller than the size of the vertebral body
Transverse processes Small and have transverse foramen, and 2 tubercles Longer, larger, and stronger; no transverse foramina 
Spinous processes Horizontally behind the body and usually bifid (C1-C5) Longer and slender; terminates in a distinct tubercle

 The images given below illustrate a typical cervical and thoracic vertebrae respectively.

The anterior tubercle of the 6th cervical vertebra is the longest and is known as the carotid tubercle of Chassaignac. The carotid artery can be compressed against the groove formed by the anterior tubercles and the vertebral bodies.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about gastroduodenal motor activity?

choices.text: Migrating motor complex (MMC) in the fasting state lasts for 50 minutes.
Duodenal slow waves are limited to the duodenum.
From the duodenum, the MMC moves distally at 5-10 cm/min.
The amplitude of contraction decreases to a minimum in phase III of MMC.

questions.solution:
From the duodenum, the migrating motor complex (MMC) moves distally at 5–10 cm/min, reaching the terminal ileum after 1.5 hours. 

In the fasting state,  there is a period of quiescence in the small bowel, lasting for approximately 40 minutes (phase I). This is followed by a series of waves, also lasting for about 40 minutes, propagating from the fundus of the stomach in a caudal direction at a rate of about 3 per minute (phase II). 

Duodenal slow waves are generated in the duodenum at a rate of about 10 per minute, which carry down the small bowel.

The amplitude of these contractions increases to a maximum in phase III, which lasts for about 10 minutes. This 90-minute cycle of activity is then repeated.

questions.text: Early maxillary carcinoma presents as
questions.solution: Early features of maxillary sinus malignancy are nasal stuffiness, blood-stained nasal discharge, facial paraesthesias or pain and epiphora. These symptoms may be missed or simply treated as sinusitis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with complaints of severe pain in the left ear. Otoscopic examination of the left ear revealed impacted wax with pearly white keratinous debris in the external auditory canal. Audiometry revealed a conductive hearing loss. Which of the following is least likely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young patient with severe otalgia, conductive hearing loss, and pearly white keratin debris in the external auditory canal is suggestive of keratosis obturans. The pressure effect due to this debris causes bone absorption leading to widening of the meatus (not narrowing).

Keratosis obturans is the accumulation of a large plug of desquamated keratin in the external auditory meatus.

Normally, epithelium from the surface of the tympanic membrane migrates onto the posterior meatal wall. Failure of this migration, or obstruction to migration caused by wax, may lead to keratosis obturans.

Features of keratosis obturans:

It is commonly seen in the younger age group and is occasionally bilateral. The presentation includes severe otalgia and conductive hearing loss. On examination,  there is thickened tympanic membrane, keratin plug/pearly white mass occluding the canal. The keratin squames are shed from the complete circumference of the deep ear canal forming a lamina giving an onion skin arrangement. There is also associated absorption of adjacent bone, hyperemia of canal skin, sometimes with ulcerations and granulations. 

idened ear canal may lead to facial nerve paralysis. Systemic conditions like bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis are associated. 

Treatment:

  • Removal of the plug by syringing or instrumentation.
  • Recurrence can be prevented with the use of keratolytic such as 2% salicylic acid.

questions.text: Involvement of the poststyloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space will not give rise to:
questions.solution:
Involvement of the poststyloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space will not give rise to Trismus.

Parapharyngeal space is divided into 2 compartments by Styloid process & its attachments:

(Clinical features depend on the compartment involved)

Presentation in poststyloid abscess is:

  • Bulge of pharynx behind the posterior pillar
  • Paralysis of CN IX, X(vocal cord paralysis), XI, and XII and sympathetic chain (Horner’s syndrome)
  • Swelling of parotid region
  • There will not be any trismus

questions.text: Anitschkow cells are seen in_____.
questions.solution:
Anitschkow cells or caterpillar cells are seen in acute rheumatic fever.

  • Acute rheumatic fever is characterized by discrete inflammatory foci within a variety of tissues.
  • The myocardial inflammatory lesions—called Aschoff bodies—are pathognomonic for rheumatic fever.
  • Aschoff bodies are collections of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), scattered plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells associated with zones of fibrinoid necrosis.
  • The Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon (hence the name “caterpillar cells”).

 

Image: Histology of a rheumatic fever patient showing Aschoff bodies and Anitschkow cells.

Related Pearl: Named Cells in Histopathology

Named cells

Condition

Anitschkow or caterpillar cells

Rheumatic heart disease

Globoid cells

Krabbe disease

Kulchitsky cells

Small cell carcinoma of lung

Signet ring cells

Signet ring cell carcinoma

Crumpled tissue paper macrophages

Gauchers disease

Clue cells

Bacterial vaginosis

Fried egg cells

Oligodendroglioma

Hallmark cells

Anaplastic large cell lymphoma

Shadow cells

Pilomatricoma

Mott cells

Plasma cell myeloma

Lepidic cells

Cardiac myxoma

Spider cells

Rhabdomyoma

questions.text: After evaluation, a patient with the given finding is diagnosed with Tuberous sclerosis, What is the mode of inheritance of this condition?
questions.solution:
Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC)/ Bourneville disease is an autosomal-dominant genetic disorder.

TSC affects the differentiation, proliferation, and migration of cells early in development. This results in a variety of hamartomatous lesions that may affect virtually every organ system of the body. Two distinct genetic loci have been identified which are on chromosome  9 (TSC1) and on chromosome 16 (TSC2).

The most common cutaneous manifestation of TSC is hypomelanotic macules (ash-leaf macules) and is observed in most children with tuberous sclerosis. It presents at birth or appears within the first few years of life and may fade or disappear in adulthood.

The following image shows an ash-leaf macule.

questions.text: An intern was asked to give an intravenous injection to a vein in the cubital fossa. All of the following are true about the cubital fossa except:

choices.text: Musculocutaneous nerve is one of the contents
Radial nerve enters the fossa laterally
Median cubital vein forms the roof

questions.solution:
The musculocutaneous nerve is not a content of the cubital fossa.

The cubital fossa is a triangular depression present in the anterior side of the elbow joint. The boundaries of the cubital fossa include:

  • Medially: Lateral border of the pronator teres
  • Laterally: Medial border of the brachioradialis (option A)
  • Base: Proximally by an imaginary line joining the epicondyles of the humerus
  • Apex (pointed downward): Joining of the lateral and medial boundaries.
  • Roof: Skin, superficial fascia containing median cubital vein (option D) joining the cephalic and basilic veins, lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, medial cutaneous nerve of the forearm, bicipital aponeurosis, and deep fascia.
  • Floor: Brachialis and supinator muscles.

The contents of the brachial fossa are (from medial to lateral side):

  • Median nerve
  • Brachial artery, terminating into radial and ulnar arteries
  • Biceps brachii tendon with the bicipital aponeurosis
  • Radial nerve enters the fossa laterally (option C) in the groove between the brachialis and brachioradialis

Clinical significance:

  • The median cubital vein is the most commonly preferred vein of choice for intravenous injections. 
  • Auscultation of the brachial artery in front of the elbow helps in measuring the blood pressure.

questions.text: Sin of Gomorrah is:
questions.solution:
Buccal coitus is also known as sin of Gomorrah / Coitus Per Os.

The male genital organ is introduced into mouth of another male or female.

Teeth marks / abrasions on the penis, semen in the respiratory tract / stomach could be the clues to diagnosis. Buccal swabs are useful only upto 9 hours. Buccal coitus can lead to death by aspiration of semen or impaction of the penis in the hypopharynx.

questions.text: The insecticide shown below is used to eliminate the larval form of
questions.solution:
The above image shows Paris green which is a commonly used larvicide against Anopheles larvae. Paris green mainly kills larvae who are surface feeders which include Anopheles larvae.

Paris green (Copper acetoarsenite) is an insecticide, which is a green powder that has 50% arsenious oxide. It is a stomach poison and to be effective, it must be ingested by the larvae. 

Other commonly used larvicides are:

  • Mineral oils - diesel oil, kerosene, fractions of crude oils, mosquito larvicidal oil
  • Synthetic insecticides - Fenthion, Chlorpyrifos, and Abate

Larvicides that are not recommended include organochlorine compounds like DDT and HCH. This is because they have a long residual effect, and contaminate water. Vector mosquitoes may also develop resistance to these compounds.

The larvae of Anopheles lie parallel to the surface of the water. They don't have a siphon tube. In their larval stage, they are surface feeders. In contrast, Culicine larvae like Aedes, Culex, Mansonia have a siphon tube that helps them to suspend in water with their head downwards.

The image below shows Laraval forms of different mosquitoes.

questions.text: Which among the following is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation?
questions.solution:
Mendelsohn manoeuver is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation.

Mendelsohn manoeuvre is a form of supraglottic swallow in which the patient imitates the upward movement of the larynx. It is done by voluntarily holding the larynx at its maximum height to prolong the duration of the cricopharyngeal opening. Patients hold the swallow for 2-3 seconds, and then complete the swallow and relax when the pharynx is in the uppermost stage. It has been used to treat patients with pharyngeal dysphagia.

Other options:

Option A: Transoral pneumatic device is an artificial larynx used in those who fail to learn oesophageal speech.  

Options B and C: Blom-Singer prosthesis and Panje prosthesis are types of tracheoesophageal prosthesis.

questions.text: Despite their short half-lives, how do proton-pump inhibitors cause prolonged suppression of acid secretion for up to 48 hours?

choices.text: Exit from plasma and enter acid secretory canaliculi, blocking the secretion of acid for a long time
Irreversibly inhibit proton pump molecule, acid secretion requires synthesis of new proton pumps
Available as enteric coated capsules from which drug is gradually released

questions.solution:
PPIs irreversibly inhibit the proton pump molecule and hence, acid secretion requires the synthesis of new proton pumps.

PPIs are prodrugs, when ingested, get absorbed into the systemic circulation. It then diffuses into the parietal cells of the stomach and accumulates in the acidic secretory canaliculi. Acidic pH in the parietal cell canaliculi causes activation of the PPIs. These activated PPIs irreversibly inhibit H+/K+ ATPase (proton pump) in the parietal cell.

The maximum proton pump activation corresponds to the peak concentration of PPI resulting in maximum efficacy.

The secretion resumes gradually over 3-4 days of stopping the drug when new proton pumps are synthesized.

questions.text: An elderly patient admitted with multiple comorbidities in the ICU, developed exposure keratitis and ulceration. An ophthalmology opinion was sought. Incidentally, on fundoscopy, the resident found the following picture. What is this most likely due to?
questions.solution:
The given image suggests a diagnosis of proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

The hallmark of Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is neovascularization. Abnormal new vessel formation, which occurs on the inner (vitreous) surface of the retina and may extend into the vitreous cavity, can cause vitreous haemorrhage. Neovascularization is often accompanied by pre-retinal fibrous tissue, which, along with the vitreous, can contract, resulting in traction retinal detachment. In addition, tiny microaneurysms can also be seen.

questions.text: Source of progesterone during normal menstrual cycle______
questions.solution: Progesterone is a C21 steroid secreted by the corpus luteum, the placenta, and (in small amounts) the fol­licle.

questions.text: Mallory- Denk bodies are made of______
questions.solution:
• Mallory-Denk bodies are made up of tangled skeins of intermediate filaments such as keratins 8 and 18 in complex with other proteins such as ubiquitin.
  • These are usually present as clumped, amorphous, the eosinophilic material in ballooned hepatocytes seen in chronic hepatitis.

Image – Mallory - Denk bodies, H and E stain.

questions.text: A diabetic patient is diagnosed with hypertension during his annual health check-up. What is the treatment of choice for him?
questions.solution:
ACE inhibitors such as captopril or ARBs can be considered as a treatment of choice in hypertensive patients with diabetes because of the renoprotective action. It benefits diabetic patients by reducing the risk of occurrence and progression of diabetic nephropathy. 

They are also recommended in patients with CKD irrespective of diabetes status as they can delay the progression of nephropathy.

Option A: Thiazide diuretics worsen glycemic control and are not preferred in diabetic patients.

Option B: Beta-blockers, especially non-selective blockers, worsen glycemic control.

Option D: Calcium channel blockers have a neutral effect on glycemic control and can be used in diabetes if ACE inhibitors or ARBs cannot be given.

questions.text: Which of the following devices can be used for a patient with bilateral external auditory canal atresia
questions.solution: A bone anchored hearing aid is used in a patient with bilateral extenal auditory canal atresia.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presented 3 months ago with mild behavioral changes. He developed startle myoclonus and progressively worsening dementia. His condition deteriorated rapidly and the patient passed away within 2 days. On autopsy, spongiform degeneration of the brain was noted. What inclusions could also be found on histopathological examination of his brain?
questions.solution:
This elderly man, with startle myoclonus, a rapidly progressive dementia that leads to death within 3 months, and spongiform degeneration of the brain on autopsy most likely had a diagnosis of prion disease (likely Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease or Kuru). Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is associated with misfolded prion protein inclusions called PrP.

Prion disease is a rapidly progressing neurodegenerative disorder that occurs due to abnormal protein folding of prion proteins. These proteins can undergo a structural change from an alpha helix to beta-pleated sheets (PrPC to PrPSc). These proteins now become resistant to breakdown by normal proteases in the body and can rapidly spread, invading the central nervous system and inducing neuronal cell death. Prion diseases can be sporadic in nature, but more often they have a familial mode of spread due to mutations in the PRNP gene that codes for PrP.

The brain classically undergoes spongiform degeneration due to vacuole formation and rapid death of the neurons. Histopathological examination during post-mortem can reveal inclusion such as PrPSC deposits and Kuru plaques. 

Other options:

Option B: Alpha-synuclein is commonly seen in Parkinson's disease, which presents with an abnormal shuffling gait, resting tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia. It can also be seen in multiple system atrophy which is predominantly a disease of autonomic dysfunction. It can progress rapidly but is not associated with startle myoclonus or progressive dementia.

Option C: Tau neurofibrillary tangles are often seen in Alzheimer's disease and frontotemporal lobe degeneration. Both these conditions do not present with rapid worsening of symptoms as seen in this patient. Alzheimer's disease causes gradually progressive dementia and presents with myoclonic jerks only at later stages. Frontotemporal lobe degeneration would result in gradual behavioral changes and features of aphasia.

Option D: Polyglutamate aggregates are seen in Huntington's disease. This disorder presents with a gradual onset of dementia and abnormal movements that progress to death over 20 years.

questions.text: Features of competitive inhibition include ________
questions.solution:
Vmax remains constant in competitive inhibition reactions.

Properties of Competitive inhibition on enzyme dynamics:

  • Vmax remains constant
  • Km increases (MNEMONIC: In competition, we run for KILOMETRES i.e. Km; Hence remember as Km increases in Competitive inhibition)
  • Reversible
  • The inhibition can be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate.
